Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Physics at Cosmology/High Energy Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors William H. Kinney and Dejan Stojkovic at the University at Buffalo, the State University of New York.

The primary purpose of this research is to address important unsolved issues of fundamental physics at the interface of cosmology, gravity and high-energy physics. Kinney's research focuses on the physics of Cosmological Inflation, the leading model for the physics of the earliest moments of the universe. This research will address the questions of observational constraints on inflation, alternatives to inflation, and probes of fundamental physics. By contrast, Stojkovic will focus on building, developing, and using the very comprehensive BlackMax computer code for simulating dark matter signatures at the Large Hadron Collider, and addressing puzzles raised by recent observational data. Joint effort by the PIs is also planned in studying alternatives to inflation and addressing the puzzles raised by recent observational data.

The research funded by this award will also have significant broader impacts. The tools developed (such as the BlackMax software package) will be made publicly available for the benefit of a wide physics community. This project will also provide an excellent training ground for students at the undergraduate and graduate levels, preparing them for future careers in scientific research. Both Kinney and Stojkovic are very active in outreach activities such as public lectures, school visits, planetarium shows, and the ongoing "Science & Art Cabaret" organized by Kinney in conjunction with Hallwall's Contemporary Art Center and the Buffalo Science Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research completed under this grant focused on in connecting high-precision cosmological and accelerator data to fundamental questions such as the origin and evolution of the universe, the unification of gravitation with quantum mechanics, the role of the vacuum in the structure of space and time. These are among the foremost unsolved issues facing physics in the twenty-first century, and this ``Physics of the Universe'' has been identified as a top NSF funding priority by the National Science and Technology Council Committee on Science. Similarly, the recently released National Research Council Decadal Survey of Astronomy and Astrophysics has identified a set of central questions for Cosmology and Fundamental Physics in the decade 2010-2020, among them:

  • How did the universe begin?
  • Why is the universe accelerating?
  • What is the dark matter?

Key outcomes from this project included:

  • Analysis of the milestone Planck observations of the Cosmic Microwave Background, the relict light from the Big Bang. Research focused on constraints on inflationary cosmology. Inflation, postulating a period of rapidly accelerating cosmological expansion, is the leading candidate theory for the evolution of the very early universe. 
  • Analysis of the BICEP2 detection of so-called B-mode polarization patterns in the Cosmic Microwave Background, which are a signature of primordial gravity waves in the early universe. The gravity wave interpretation of the data has come under significant scrutiny, particularly in light of the release of Planck polarization data, which indicate that the BICEP2 signal is either wholly or partly due to dust in our own galaxy. Whether or not primordial gravitational waves will be found to be at a level which is possible to detect is still an open question, but such a detection would have profound consequences for our understanding of the very early universe. 
  • Analysis of alternatives to inflation, including "bouncing" cosmologies in which the Big Bang was preceded by a period of cosmological contraction, and "tachyacoustic" cosmologies, in which the speed of sound exceeds the speed of light. Kinney, in collaboration with Ghaszal Geshnizjani and Azadeh Moradinezhad, derived general, model-independent bounds on the physics of the very early universe in order to be consistent with observational data. 
  • Event generator BlackMax has been updated to include perturbative string theory signature at the LHC.  
  • Generalization of a class of DGP models known as the "cascading gravity" models  was done. The resulting models are free of ghosts and extend the solutions known so far.
  • A stringy model of stohastically evolving dimensions was constructed where the dimensionality of our space depends on the energy/temperature that we are probing. It was demonstrated how a discrete causal set and eventually a continuum arise from the string world sheet action. The Planck scale and the string scale are related without any compactification.     
  • Quantum effects in the strong gravity regime were studied. Among the other things, it was shown that the last stage of the gravitational collapse is described by non-local (but also non-singular) physics. 

Broader impacts included research training for both graduate and undergraduate students, as well as numerous conference presentations and public talks. Among the notable outreach efforts completed during the period of this grant was the continuation of the successful "Science & Art Cabaret" event, which has shown enduring public appeal, with thirteen events held during the life of this award.
